Abrams and One Georgia sued last month, arguing that the law was unconstitutional, and further that she should be exempt from fundraising caps since she has no opponent in the May 24 Democratic primary, making her the party's de facto nominee.

In 2021, Georgia's Republican-controlled General Assembly passed a law that exempts some incumbentsparticularly the governor and lieutenant governoras well as party nominees for elected offices from fundraising caps on their campaigns.

A federal judge issued a ruling in a case over a political fundraising law in Georgia that will put Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams and even some Republicans at a big disadvantage as they try to unseat Gov.
Candidates in those positions can create so-called leadership committees that don't have to abide by the $7,600 cap on donations from individuals in general elections, while all other candidates do.
The law was clearly intended to give Kemp an advantage on fundraising in the lead up to this year's gubernatorial race, as Abrams has proven a formidable fundraiser since her last campaign in 2018.
The leadership committees can also coordinate directly with candidates' campaigns, something that a traditional political action committee, such as Abrams' One Georgia, cannot do.
With the law in place, it effectively gives Kemp a head start over Abrams and even his Republican challengers like former U.S. Sen. David Perdue, who filed a separate lawsuit.
